newsitem.title: USA: Central Calif. coho salmon listed as threatened.
newsitem.headline: Central Calif. coho salmon listed as threatened.

text.p: The National Marine Fisheries Service said Friday it has decided to list the dwindling central California coho salmon as a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act.

The service said it was deferring by six months a decision on whether to list two other species of coho salmon found in northern California and Oregon because of substantial scientific disagreement about them.
The decision, eagerly awaited by environmentalists and officials in California and Oregon, was seen as highly sensitive in an election year.
Once a species is listed under the Endangered Species Act, industrial activity, development and water usage that could harm its habitat are closely scrutinized by the authorities.

California Gov. Pete Wilson wrote to President Clinton Thursday urging him to delay the listing of the coho salmon, saying it could lead to "a virtual shutdown of logging, mining, ranching and other agricultural activity over large parts of California."

Fisheries Service spokesman Brian Gorman said it was clear that the central California coho salmon were in "dire straits". Their numbers had fallen from 100,000 in the 1940s to about 6,000 adults that were now returning each year to spawning streams. "That's enough to make anybody sit up and take notice," he said.
